description: From Middle English quest, queste; partly from Anglo-Norman queste, Old French queste (“acquisition, search, hunt”), and partly from their source, Latin quaesta (“tribute, tax, inquiry, search”), noun use of quaesita, the feminine past participle of quaerere (“to ask, seek”).

entries.meaning: A journey or effort in pursuit of a goal (often lengthy, ambitious, or fervent); a mission.
The act of seeking, or looking after anything; attempt to find or obtain; search; pursuit.
examples: to rove in quest of game, of a lost child, of property, etc.
Gad not abroad at every quest and call / Of an untrained hope or passion.

entries.meaning: (obsolete) A group of people making search or inquiry.

verbs.description: quest (third-person singular simple present quests, present participle questing, simple past and past participle quested)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To seek or pursue a goal; to undertake a mission or job.
(transitive) To search for something; to seek.
examples: Next day we quested in search of our caravan, and after some pains recovered it.

entries.meaning: (entomology, of a tick) To locate and attach to a host animal.

description: Blend of quiz +‎ test, to avoid using the word test.
